SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Quantitative), for which students must use quantitative evidence (i.e., data from an informational graphic) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice best describes a major theme of the passage?

A.Choice: The corrupting influence of a materialistic society

Key.Rationale: Even if the passage implies that Silas was too materialistic before his daughter's arrival in his life, his greediness was a personal characteristic only, not a societal one; whether the society Silas lives in is overly materialistic is never addressed.

B.Choice: The moral purity of young children

Key.Rationale: Even if the passage represents the “moral purity” of children, it does so only indirectly and not as a major theme.

C.Choice: The bittersweet brevity of childhood naïveté

Key.Rationale: The passage addresses childhood enthusiasm and curiosity more than “naïveté” and never discusses the length or “brevity” of that naïveté.

D.Choice: The restorative power of parental love

Key.Rationale: The final sentence of the first paragraph makes clear that before adopting his daughter, the weaver Silas was greedy for gold and chained to his work, “deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom.” But after adopting Eppie, Silas became more interested in life outside his job: “Eppie called him away from his weaving, and made him think all its pauses a holiday, reawakening his senses with her fresh life.” A major theme of the passage can be seen in this transformation, as it represents how loving a child can improve or change a parent's life.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: As compared with Silas's gold, Eppie is portrayed as having more

A.Choice: vitality.

Key.Rationale: The first sentence of the first paragraph notes that “Unlike the gold ... Eppie was a creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires, seeking and loving sunshine, and living sounds, and living movements; making trial of everything, with trust in new joy, and stirring the human kindness in all eyes that looked on her.” These lines make clear that in contrast to Silas's gold, his new daughter is vibrant and alive.

B.Choice: durability.

Key.Rationale: The lines from the first paragraph cited above reveal Eppie's interest in “living sounds” and “living movements” and thus characterize her vitality in comparison to the gold, rather than her durability.

C.Choice: protection.

Key.Rationale: The lines from the first paragraph cited above reveal Eppie's interest in “living sounds” and “living movements” and thus characterize her vitality in comparison to the gold, rather than her protection.

D.Choice: self sufficiency.

Key.Rationale: The lines from the first paragraph cited above reveal Eppie's interest in “living sounds” and “living movements” and thus characterize her vitality in comparison to the gold, rather than her  self-sufficiency.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: Which statement best describes a technique the narrator uses to represent Silas's character before he adopted Eppie?

A.Choice: The narrator emphasizes Silas's former obsession with wealth by depicting his gold as requiring certain behaviors on his part.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph, the narrator describes Silas as having been so obsessed as to have felt required to worship the gold “in close-locked solitude,” with “his thoughts in an ever-repeated circle” centered on his hoard. Moreover, this obsession compelled him to “sit weaving longer and longer, deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web.” These lines convey the extent to which Silas's behaviors were determined by his obsession.

B.Choice: The narrator underscores Silas's former greed by describing his gold as seeming to reproduce on its own.

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not make it seem as if Silas's gold could reproduce on its own, with the first paragraph suggesting that his hoard was a consequence of hard work, his being “deafened and blinded more and more to all things except the monotony of his loom and the repetition of his web.”

C.Choice: The narrator hints at Silas's former antisocial attitude by contrasting his present behavior toward his neighbors with his past behavior toward them.

Key.Rationale: Even if the first paragraph mentions that, after Eppie's arrival, Silas thinks about “the ties and charities that bound together the families of his neighbors,” the passage never addresses how Silas interacted with those neighbors previously.

D.Choice: The narrator demonstrates Silas's former lack of self-awareness by implying that he is unable to recall life before Eppie.

Key.Rationale: The third paragraph makes clear that Silas is not only able to recall life before Eppie, but that with her in his life, “his mind was growing into memory.”

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: The narrator uses the phrase “making trial of everything” (line 7) to present Eppie as

A.Choice: friendly.

Key.Rationale: In the context of her “making trial of everything,” Eppie can be seen as curious, not friendly.

B.Choice: curious.

Key.Rationale: The first paragraph of the passage describes Eppie as “a creature of endless claims and ever-growing desires,” one who is “making trial of everything.” In this context, her “making trial of everything” can be read as her acting on her curiosity by striving to experience the world around her.

C.Choice: disobedient.

Key.Rationale: In the context of her “making trial of everything,” Eppie can be seen as curious, not disobedient.

D.Choice: judgmental.

Key.Rationale: In the context of her “making trial of everything,” Eppie can be seen as curious, not judgmental.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: According to the narrator, one consequence of Silas adopting Eppie is that he

A.Choice: has renounced all desire for money.

Key.Rationale: Although the passage implies that Silas is less obsessed with money than before, there is no indication that he has actually renounced his desire for it.

B.Choice: better understands his place in nature.

Key.Rationale: Although the passage explains that Silas spends time outdoors after the arrival of Eppie, there is no indication that her presence has necessarily changed his understanding of his place in nature.

C.Choice: seems more accepting of help from others.

Key.Rationale: At no point in the passage is Silas shown accepting help from anyone.

D.Choice: looks forward to a different kind of future.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph, the narrator indicates that with the arrival of Eppie, Silas's thoughts turn from his work and his gold toward Eppie's future and his life with her: “Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank limit — carried them away to the new things that would come with the coming years.” By influencing Silas to think “onward” and of “the coming years,” Eppie prompts Silas to envision a far different future than he would experience otherwise.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 9-11 (“The gold ... itself”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the consequence of Silas's adoption of Eppie, instead describing Silas's life before Eppie entered it.

B.Choice: Lines 11-16 (“but Eppie ... years”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks what consequence Silas has experienced as a result of adopting Eppie. The answer, that he begins to imagine a new future for himself and her, is supported in the first paragraph: “but Eppie was an object compacted of changes and hopes that forced his thoughts onward, and carried them far away from their old eager pacing towards the same blank limit — carried them away to the new things that would come with the coming years.”

C.Choice: Lines 41-43 (“Then ... stillness”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the consequence of Silas's adoption of Eppie, instead describing how he occasionally acts in her presence.

D.Choice: Lines 61-63 (“shapes ... for”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the consequence of Silas's adoption of Eppie, instead describing the changes in Eppie's perception of the world as she ages.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: What function does the second paragraph (lines 30-52) serve in the passage as a whole?

A.Choice: It presents the particular moment at which Silas realized that Eppie was changing him.

Key.Rationale: The second paragraph does not present a particular moment when Silas realizes that Eppie has changed him but instead describes a pattern of behavior indicative of that change.

B.Choice: It highlights Silas's love for Eppie by depicting the sacrifices that he makes for her.

Key.Rationale: The second paragraph shows the benefits Silas derives from Eppie's presence, rather than any sacrifices he has made for her.

C.Choice: It illustrates the effect that Eppie has on Silas by describing the interaction between them.

Key.Rationale: In the second paragraph, the description of Silas and Eppie's interaction outdoors conveys the extent to which he has changed since her arrival: where he once worked all day at his loom to earn more and more money, he now “might be seen in the sunny mid-day” strolling with her, accepting the flowers she brings him, or listening to birdcalls with her. With these experiences also come “crowding remembrances” of his early life — the life he led before amassing his hoard of gold. In its entirety, the paragraph can therefore be seen as illustrating the profound change into a more sociable being that Silas has undergone as a result of parenting Eppie.

D.Choice: It reveals a significant alteration in the relationship between Silas and Eppie.

Key.Rationale: The second paragraph dramatizes a change in Silas's life overall, rather than showing a change in the dynamic that has arisen between Silas and Eppie.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: In describing the relationship between Eppie and Silas, the narrator draws a connection between Eppie's

A.Choice: physical vulnerability and Silas's emotional fragility.

Key.Rationale: The narrator portrays Eppie as being curious and eager, not physically vulnerable, and also implies that Silas is becoming ever more emotionally robust, not psychologically fragile.

B.Choice: expanding awareness and Silas's increasing engagement with life.

Key.Rationale: The third paragraph of the passage shows that as Eppie learns more and more, Silas reengages with life: “As the child's mind was growing into knowledge, his mind was growing into memory: as her life unfolded, his soul, long stupefied in a cold narrow prison, was unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness.” As Eppie grows into a world that is new to her, Silas recovers a world he'd largely forgotten.

C.Choice: boundless energy and Silas's insatiable desire for wealth.

Key.Rationale: The only connection the narrator makes regarding Silas's former greed and Eppie's presence in his life is that she has brought an end to his obsessive pursuit of wealth.

D.Choice: physical growth and Silas's painful perception of his own mortality.

Key.Rationale: The narrator does not address Silas's mortality in any way but rather shows him becoming more and more alive through Eppie's love.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 1-9 (“Unlike ... her”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the connection between Eppie and Silas, instead contrasting Silas's fixation on his gold with Eppie's curiosity.

B.Choice: Lines 30-41 (“And when ... flowers”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the connection between Eppie and Silas, instead describing Silas's habitual behavior when accompanying Eppie outdoors.

C.Choice: Lines 46-48 (“Sitting ... again”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about the connection between Eppie and Silas, instead describing Silas's habitual behavior when accompanying Eppie outdoors.

D.Choice: Lines 53-57 (“As the ... consciousness”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks what connection the narrator draws between Eppie and Silas. The answer, that as she learns more about the world, he becomes more involved in it, is supported in the third paragraph: “As the child's mind was growing into knowledge, his mind was growing into memory: as her alife unfolded, his soul, long stupefied in a cold narrow prison, was unfolding too, and trembling gradually into full consciousness.”

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 65, “fine” most nearly means

A.Choice: acceptable.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a description in which Eppie was said to have a “fine capacity for mischief,” the word “fine” most nearly means keen, or acute, not acceptable.

B.Choice: delicate.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a description in which Eppie was said to have a “fine capacity for mischief,” the word “fine” most nearly means keen, or acute, not delicate.

C.Choice: ornate.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a description in which Eppie was said to have a “fine capacity for mischief,” the word “fine” most nearly means keen, or acute, not ornate.

D.Choice: keen.

Key.Rationale: In the last paragraph, the narrator states, “Also, by the time Eppie was three years old, she developed a fine capacity for mischief, and for devising ingenious ways of being troublesome.” In this context, the word “fine” most nearly means keen, or acute.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: The main purpose of the passage is to

A.Choice: examine the role of technology in workers' lives during the last century.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not examine how workers' lives have been affected by technology during the last century.

B.Choice: advocate for better technology to enhance workplace conditions.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not advocate for a course of action; instead, the passage considers both sides of an issue, taking no position of its own.

C.Choice: argue for changes in how technology is deployed in the workplace.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not argue for a course of action; instead, the passage considers both sides of an issue, taking no position of its own.

D.Choice: assess the impact of advancements in technology on overall job growth.

Key.Rationale: The first paragraph of the passage explains the theory of two MIT business scholars who believe that technological advances in the workplace could lead to fewer jobs for human workers, explaining that they “foresee dismal prospects for many types of jobs as these powerful new technologies are increasingly adopted not only in manufacturing, clerical, and retail work but in professions such as law, financial services, education, and medicine.” The fifth paragraph of the passage, however, offer a contrasting view, citing a Harvard economist who “says that no historical pattern shows these shifts leading to a net decrease in jobs over an extended period.” Combined, these different opinions indicate the main purpose of the passage, which is to assess how new technologies in the workplace might affect job growth as a whole.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: According to Brynjolfsson and McAfee, advancements in technology since approximately the year 2000 have resulted in

A.Choice: low job growth in the United States.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph of the passage, Brynjolfsson and McAfee clearly state that technological advances since the year 2000 have led to low job growth in the United States: “MIT business scholars Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee have argued that impressive advances in computer technology — from improved industrial robotics to automated translation services — are largely behind the sluggish employment growth of the last 10 to 15 years.”

B.Choice: global workplace changes.

Key.Rationale: Although Brynjolfsson and McAfee assert that certain “changes” have occurred in the workplace as a result of technological advancement, they offer only tentative speculation that those changes may be reflected globally.

C.Choice: more skilled laborers in the United States.

Key.Rationale: The passage notes a decrease, rather than an increase, in skilled laborers.

D.Choice: no global creation of new jobs.

Key.Rationale: The passage makes no mention of the global creation of new jobs, even speculating that jobs may have been negatively impacted in technologically advanced nations.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 1-6 (“MIT ... years”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks what Brynjolfsson and McAfee say has resulted in the workplace from advances in technology since the year 2000. The answer, that low job growth has resulted from these advances, is supported in the first sentence of the first paragraph: “MIT business scholars Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee have argued that impressive advances in computer technology — from improved industrial robotics to automated translation services — are largely behind the sluggish employment growth of the last 10 to 15 years.”

B.Choice: Lines 13-15 (“That ... agent”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Brynjolfsson and McAfee say has resulted in the workplace from advances in technology since the year 2000; instead they point to industries not under specific consideration by Brynjolfsson and McAfee.

C.Choice: Lines 21-23 (“And ... countries”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Brynjolfsson and McAfee say has resulted in the workplace from advances in technology since the year 2000; instead they speculate as to whether changes might also be happening in other countries.

D.Choice: Lines 35-38 (“as businesses ... jobs”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Brynjolfsson and McAfee say has resulted in the workplace from advances in technology since the year 2000; instead they explain the importance of productivity in the marketplace in the decades following World War II.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: The primary purpose of lines 26-28 (“the amount ... labor”) is to

A.Choice: describe a process.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the appositive (“the amount of economic value ... such as an hour of labor”) is clearly provided to help explain the term “productivity,” not to describe a process.

B.Choice: highlight a dilemma.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the appositive (“the amount of economic value ... such as an hour of labor”) is clearly provided to help explain the term “productivity,” not to highlight a dilemma.

C.Choice: clarify a claim.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the appositive (“the amount of economic value ... such as an hour of labor”) is clearly provided to help explain the term “productivity,” not to clarify a claim.

D.Choice: explain a term.

Key.Rationale: The second sentence of the third paragraph reads, “In economics, productivity — the amount of economic value created for a given unit of input, such as an hour of labor — is a crucial indicator of growth and wealth creation.” In this context, the primary purpose of the appositive (“the amount of economic value ... such as an hour of labor”) is to define “productivity.”

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 35, “clear” most nearly means

A.Choice: pure.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the word “clear” can be seen to mean obvious, or unmistakable, not pure.

B.Choice: keen.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the word “clear” can be seen to mean obvious, or unmistakable, not keen.

C.Choice: untroubled.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the third paragraph, the word “clear” can be seen to mean obvious, or unmistakable, not untroubled.

D.Choice: unmistakable.

Key.Rationale: The third paragraph states that “the pattern is clear: as businesses generated more value from their workers, the country as a whole became richer.” In this context, the word “clear” most nearly means obvious, or unmistakable.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: Which of the following best characterizes Katz's attitude toward “today's digital technologies” (lines 81-82)?

A.Choice: He is alarmed about countries' increasing reliance on them.

Key.Rationale: It would not be accurate to characterize Katz as being alarmed about today's digital technologies. Rather, it's clear from the conclusion of the sixth paragraph that Katz isn't sure how technological advancement will affect the workplace: “If technology disrupts enough, who knows what will happen?”

B.Choice: He is unconcerned about their effect on the economy.

Key.Rationale: It would not be accurate to characterize Katz as being unconcerned about today's digital technologies. Rather, it's clear from the conclusion of the sixth paragraph that Katz isn't sure how technological advancement will affect the workplace: “If technology disrupts enough, who knows what will happen?”

C.Choice: He is uncertain how they might affect job growth.

Key.Rationale: Katz doesn't necessarily agree with Brynjolfsson and McAfee that new technologies will lead to sluggish job growth, saying in the fifth paragraph that “no historical pattern shows these shifts leading to a net decrease in jobs over an extended period.” However, he's not sure that will remain true, explaining in the sixth paragraph that no one can be certain what is going to happen to the workplace as a result of these new technologies: “If technology disrupts enough, who knows what will happen?”

D.Choice: He is optimistic that they will spur job creation to a degree not seen since the mid-nineteenth century.

Key.Rationale: It would not be accurate to characterize Katz as being optimistic about today's digital technologies. Rather, it's clear from the conclusion of the sixth paragraph that Katz isn't sure how technological advancement will affect the workplace: “If technology disrupts enough, who knows what will happen?”

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 68-72 (“Katz ... factories”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question Katz's attitude toward “today's digital technologies”; instead, they describe some of his earlier research.

B.Choice: Lines 73-75 (“While ... jobs”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question Katz's attitude toward “today's digital technologies”; instead, they provide insight only into his initial thoughts but not his final conclusion on the matter.

C.Choice: Line 79 (“People come ... do”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question Katz's attitude toward “today's digital technologies”; instead, they provide insight only into his initial thoughts but not his final conclusion on the matter.

D.Choice: Lines 91-92 (“If ... happen”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks how Katz's attitude toward “today's digital technologies” can best be characterized. The answer, that he is uncertain about their possible effects, is supported in the final sentence of the sixth paragraph: “If technology disrupts enough, who knows what will happen?”

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 83, “range” most nearly means

A.Choice: region.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the sentence, the “range” of work being discussed means the array or scope of work, not a physical delineation like a region.

B.Choice: scope.

Key.Rationale: The sixth paragraph of the passage states that “Katz doesn't dismiss the notion that there is something different about today's digital technologies — something that could affect an even broader range of work.” In the context of this sentence, the “range” of work being discussed means the scope of work or all the various kinds of work.

C.Choice: distance.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the sentence, the “range” of work being discussed means the array or scope of work, not a physical delineation like distance.

D.Choice: position.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the sentence, the “range” of work being discussed means the array or scope of work, not the professional position of those who perform particular jobs.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Quantitative), for which students must use quantitative evidence (i.e., data from an informational graphic) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: According to figure 1, which of the following years showed the widest gap between percentages of productivity and employment?

Key.Rationale: Figure 1 shows a gap of well over 100 percentage points between 2013 employment and 2013 productivity in relation to 1947 levels, while 1987 shows a difference of about 30 percentage points or less between employment and productivity.

Figure 1 shows a gap of well over 100 percentage points between 2013 employment and 2013 productivity in relation to 1947 levels, while 1997 shows a difference of about 30 percentage points or less between employment and productivity.

Figure 1 shows a gap of well over 100 percentage points between 2013 employment and 2013 productivity in relation to 1947 levels, while 2007 indicates a difference of approximately 100 percentage points.

Figure 1 shows the highest gap between the percentages of productivity and employment in relation to 1947 levels occurring in 2013, when there was a difference of approximately 150 percentage points between 2013 employment (under 400%) and 2013 productivity (well over 500%).

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Quantitative), for which students must use quantitative evidence (i.e., data from an informational graphic) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which statement is supported by figure 2?

A.Choice: The country with the greatest growth in output per manufacturing worker from 1960 to 1990 was Germany.

Key.Rationale: Figure 2 shows that Japan saw greater growth in output between 1960 and 1990 than Germany saw.

B.Choice: Japan experienced its smallest increase in output per manufacturing worker from 2000 to 2011.

Key.Rationale: Figure 2 shows that Japan experienced its greatest increase in output from 2000 to 2011, not its smallest.

C.Choice: Each of the three countries experienced an increase in its output per manufacturing worker from 1960 to 2011.

Key.Rationale: Figure 2 clearly shows an increase of worker output in all three countries between 1960 and 2011, with workers in each country producing on average less than 50 units of output in 1960 but more than 100 units by 2011.

D.Choice: Of the three countries, the United States had the greatest output per manufacturing worker for each of the years shown.

Key.Rationale: Figure 2 shows that the United States had the greatest output of all three countries only in 2011, not in each of the years shown.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which additional information, if presented in figure 2, would be most useful in evaluating the statement in lines 57-60 (“Productivity ... jobs”)?

A.Choice: The median income of employees as it compares across all three countries in a single year

Key.Rationale: A comparison of the median income of all three nations' factory workers within a single year would not aid in the evaluation of Brynjolfsson's statement regarding changes in worker productivity over a span of 10 to 15 years.

B.Choice: The number of people employed in factories from 1960 to 2011

Key.Rationale: In the fourth paragraph, Brynjolfsson asserts, “Productivity is at record levels, innovation has never been faster, and yet at the same time, we have a falling median income and we have fewer jobs.” In order to evaluate his statement that today “we have fewer jobs,” figure 2 would need to include accurate information about the number of jobs held by people employed in factories from 1960 to 2011. Without knowing those numbers, it's not possible to determine whether Brynjolfsson's statement is correct.

C.Choice: The types of organizations at which output of employed persons was measured

Key.Rationale: Knowing the types of organizations where those outputs were measured would not be helpful in evaluating Brynjolfsson's statement about how median incomes have fallen and job growth has reduced over time.

D.Choice: The kinds of manufacturing tasks most frequently taken over by machines

Key.Rationale: Knowing which specific manufacturing jobs might have been lost to new technologies would not be helpful in evaluating Brynjolfsson's statement about how median incomes have fallen and job growth has reduced over time.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: The main purpose of the passage is to

A.Choice: describe how squadrons of planes can save fuel by flying in a V formation.

Key.Rationale: The squadrons of planes mentioned in the second paragraph are used as an example to discuss migrating birds but are not themselves the main subject of this passage.

B.Choice: discuss the effects of downdrafts on birds and airplanes.

Key.Rationale: Although the fourth paragraph does discuss the role of downdrafts in V-formation flight, this discussion is brief and does not constitute a main purpose.

C.Choice: explain research conducted to study why some birds fly in a V formation.

Key.Rationale: The main purpose of the passage is conveyed by the first sentence: “Anyone watching the autumn sky knows that migrating birds fly in a V formation, but scientists have long debated why.” The first paragraph continues by focusing on new research that might answer the question of why birds fly in that formation (“presumably to catch the preceding bird's updraft — and save energy during flight”). As a whole, the passage can therefore be seen as a discussion of the biological motivation behind migrating birds' reliance on the V formation.

D.Choice: illustrate how birds sense air currents through their feathers.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not illustrate how birds sense air currents through their feathers; instead, the seventh paragraph suggests in passing that such sensation may play a role in maintaining the V formation: “Scientists do not know how the birds find that aerodynamic sweet spot, but they suspect that the animals align themselves either by sight or by sensing air currents through their feathers.”

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: The author includes the quotation “Air gets pretty unpredictable behind a flapping wing” (lines 17-18) to

A.Choice: explain that the current created by a bird differs from that of an airplane.

Key.Rationale: In the second paragraph of the passage, the quotation “Air gets pretty unpredictable behind a flapping wing” immediately follows the statement that “currents created by airplanes are far more stable than the oscillating eddies coming off of a bird.” The inclusion of the above quotation can therefore be seen as a way to explain that the current created by a bird's flapping wings is different from the current coming off the fixed wing of an airplane.

B.Choice: stress the amount of control exerted by birds flying in a V formation.

Key.Rationale: The quotation's explanation that air is “unpredictable” behind a bird's wing stresses the bird's lack of control over the air current.

C.Choice: indicate that wind movement is continuously changing.

Key.Rationale: The quotation attributes the unpredictability of the current “behind a flapping wind” to the action of the wing rather than to wind, and in fact the passage makes no mention of wind.

D.Choice: emphasize that the flapping of a bird's wings is powerful.

Key.Rationale: The quotation characterizes the flapping of the bird's wings in terms of the unpredictability of its effects, not of its comparative strength.

SubTopics: Inferences, for which students must draw a reasonable inference based on explicit and/or implicit information and ideas in a text.
Content: What can reasonably be inferred about the reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study?

A.Choice: The ibises were well acquainted with their migration route.

Key.Rationale: It would not be accurate to say that ibises were well acquainted with their migration route, as the third paragraph explains that scientists needed to “show hand-raised birds their ancestral migration route.”

B.Choice: Usherwood knew the ibises were familiar with carrying data loggers during migration.

Key.Rationale: The third paragraph states that the ibises wore “data loggers specially built by Usherwood and his lab” but never indicates that they had worn any such device before or undertaken migration previously.

C.Choice: The ibises have a body design that is similar to that of a modern airplane.

Key.Rationale: The passage never claims that ibises' body shape is similar to the design of a modern airplane, instead comparing only a V formation of birds to an airplane in the fourth paragraph.

D.Choice: The ibises were easily accessible for Usherwood and his team to track and observe.

Key.Rationale: The reason Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subjects of his study is clearly stated at the beginning of the third paragraph: “The study, published in Nature, took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) to Europe.” Because the project reintroducing those birds was already underway, it was therefore easy for Usherwood and his team to join it.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 3-7 (“A new ... flight”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question as to why Usherwood chose northern bald ibises as the subject of his study; instead, they describe the results of the study.

B.Choice: Lines 10-12 (“Squadrons ... same”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question as to why Usherwood chose northern bald ibises as the subject of his study; instead, they compare birds and planes in flight.

C.Choice: Lines 22-24 (“The study ... Europe”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks why Usherwood used northern bald ibises as the subject of his study. The answer, that he had easy access to them because they were being used in another scientific study, is supported at the beginning of the passage's third paragraph: “The study, published in Nature, took advantage of an existing project to reintroduce endangered northern bald ibises (Geronticus eremita) to Europe.”

D.Choice: Lines 29-31 (“The device's ... flaps”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question as to why Usherwood chose northern bald ibises as the subject of his study; instead, they describe one element of the actual study but not the reason ibises were chosen.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: What is the most likely reason the author includes the 30 cm measurement in line 30?

A.Choice: To demonstrate the accuracy with which the data loggers collected the data

Key.Rationale: At the end of the third paragraph the author notes that the GPS tracking devices attached to the birds “determined each bird's flight position to within 30 cm.” This detail, along with the author's mention in the same sentence of another device that measured the timing of the wing flaps, provides evidence for the inference that the author likely specified 30 cm to underscore Usherwood's use of precise data-collection methods.

B.Choice: To present recorded data about how far an ibis flies between successive wing flaps

Key.Rationale: The passage does not state that the distance an ibis flies between wing flaps was something that could be ascertained by Usherwood's study.

C.Choice: To provide the wingspan length of a juvenile ibis

Key.Rationale: The passage does not discuss the wingspan length of juvenile ibises or suggest that this length could be determined from Usherwood's tracking data.

D.Choice: To show how far behind the microlight plane each ibis flew

Key.Rationale: The passage does not discuss the distance maintained between the plane and the ibises in flight.

SubTopics: Inferences, for which students must draw a reasonable inference based on explicit and/or implicit information and ideas in a text.
Content: What does the author imply about pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation?

A.Choice: They communicate with each other in the same way as do ibises.

Key.Rationale: The passage focuses entirely on bird flight, not bird communication.

B.Choice: They have the same migration routes as those of ibises.

Key.Rationale: The passage discusses pelicans, storks, and geese only with respect to their drafting behavior, not in terms of their migration routes.

C.Choice: They create a similar wake to that of ibises.

Key.Rationale: At the beginning of the fifth paragraph the passage states that “the findings likely apply to other long-winged birds, such as pelicans, storks, and geese, Usherwood says. Smaller birds create more complex wakes that would make drafting too difficult.” In these lines the author therefore implies that unlike smaller birds, pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation likely create a similar wake to that of ibises.

D.Choice: They expend more energy than do ibises

Key.Rationale: The passage discusses pelicans, storks, and geese only with respect to their drafting behavior, not in terms of how much energy they might expend when flying.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 35-38 (“When ... body”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question regarding what the author implies about pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation. Instead, they explain one finding in the ibis study, with no reference to other long-winged species.

B.Choice: Lines 47-48 (“Smaller ... difficult”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks what the author implies about pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation. The answer, that they produce a similar wake to ibises, is supported at the beginning of the fifth paragraph: “Smaller birds create more complex wakes that would make drafting too difficult.” This sentence, in conjunction with the preceding sentence's assertion of the probable applicability of Usherwood's findings to pelicans, storks, and geese, underscores that the point of probable similarity between ibises and those other species is in their wake and the drafting it makes possible.

C.Choice: Lines 52-54 (“Previous ... a V”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question regarding what the author implies about pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation. Instead, they highlight the findings of a previous study of energy use in bird flight, with no reference to the relationship between ibises and other species.

D.Choice: Lines 66-67 (“Alternatively ... resistance”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question regarding what the author implies about pelicans, storks, and geese flying in a V formation. Instead, they offer a theory about ibises in flight, again with no reference to other species.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: What is a main idea of the seventh paragraph (lines 62-73)?

A.Choice: Different types of hierarchies exist in each flock of birds.

Key.Rationale: Neither the seventh paragraph nor the passage as a whole is concerned with bird hierarchies; the decision as to which bird sets the “course” or “pace” is mentioned only as another aspect of bird flight that scientists have yet to explain fully.

B.Choice: Mistakes can happen when long-winged birds create a V formation.

Key.Rationale: The seventh paragraph only briefly mentions mistakes in V-formation flight, and this subject is not a central focus of the paragraph.

C.Choice: Future research will help scientists to better understand V formations.

Key.Rationale: The seventh paragraph speculates that further research may provide insight into how and why birds fly in formation: “In future studies, the researchers will switch to more common birds, such as pigeons or geese. They plan to investigate how the animals decide who sets the course and the pace.” In sum, the seventh paragraph can therefore be seen as recognizing that more research is needed to explain the phenomenon of flight formation more completely.

D.Choice: Long-winged birds watch the lead bird closely to keep a V formation in tact.

Key.Rationale: Although the seventh paragraph mentions the sighting of a lead bird or “leader” as a possible factor in the V formation, this factor is mentioned briefly and in conjunction with other factors, so that to describe it as a main idea would misrepresent the paragraph as a whole.

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: The author uses the phrase “aerodynamic sweet spot” in line 63 most likely to

A.Choice: describe how the proper structural design of an airplane helps to save fuel.

Key.Rationale: The author uses the phrase “aerodynamic sweet spot” in relation to bird flight, not plane flight.

B.Choice: show that flying can be an exhilarating experience.

Key.Rationale: The phrase is not meant to imply the joy of flight so much as the optimum efficiency that can be found by flying in a certain position.

C.Choice: describe the birds' synchronized wing movement.

Key.Rationale: The phrase is not used to discuss synchronized wing movement among birds, nor is synchronization addressed anywhere in the seventh paragraph.

D.Choice: suggest that a certain position in a V formation has the least amount of wind resistance.

Key.Rationale: In describing the way that long-winged birds like ibises fly in a V formation by drafting off each other, the seventh paragraph begins by stating, “scientists do not know how the birds find that aerodynamic sweet spot.” In context, the phrase “aerodynamic sweet spot” characterizes the particular spatial relationship among birds in the formation that affords the least amount of wind resistance and is thus beneficial for flock members to maintain.

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 72, “ripple” most nearly means

A.Choice: fluctuate.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the seventh paragraph, to “ripple” through the flock means to spread through it progressively, not to fluctuate.

B.Choice: spread.

Key.Rationale: In the seventh paragraph, the passage explains that one aspect of bird flight that awaits further study by scientists is the question of whether “a mistake made by the leader can ripple through the rest of the flock to cause traffic jams.” In this context, to say that a mistake might “ripple” through the flock most nearly means that it might progressively spread through the flock.

C.Choice: wave.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the seventh paragraph, to “ripple” through the flock means to spread through it progressively, not to wave or move in the pattern of the ebb and flow of waves.

D.Choice: undulate.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the seventh paragraph, to “ripple” through the flock means to spread through it progressively, not to undulate or move in a manner that creates a textured, undulating appearance.

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 9, “raise” most nearly means

A.Choice: increase.

Key.Rationale: In the context of Tocqueville's prediction that women will attain a higher social position, the word “raise” most nearly means elevate, not increase.

B.Choice: cultivate.

Key.Rationale: In the context of Tocqueville's prediction that women will attain a higher social position, the word “raise” most nearly means elevate, not cultivate or support.

C.Choice: nurture.

Key.Rationale: In the context of Tocqueville's prediction that women will attain a higher social position, the word “raise” most nearly means elevate, not nurture.

D.Choice: elevate.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph of Passage 1, Tocqueville predicts that “the social changes which bring nearer to the same level the father and son, the master and servant, and superiors and inferiors generally speaking, will raise woman and make her more and more the equal of man.” In this context, to “raise” women to a higher social position most nearly means to elevate, or lift, them.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: In Passage 1, Tocqueville implies that treatment of men and women as identical in nature would have which consequence?

A.Choice: Neither sex would feel oppressed.

Key.Rationale: Tocqueville says treating men and women as identical in nature would result in the degradation of both genders, a condition closer to oppression than to freedom from oppression.

B.Choice: Both sexes would be greatly harmed.

Key.Rationale: In Passage 1, Tocqueville expresses concern that treating men and women as identical would likely harm both genders, rather than benefit them. This sentiment can be seen most clearly in the second paragraph, when he writes that “it may readily be conceived, that by thus attempting to make one sex equal to the other, both are degraded.”

C.Choice: Men would try to reclaim their lost authority.

Key.Rationale: Tocqueville does not address the issue of whether men might ultimately try to reclaim any authority they lost as a result of the treatment of both genders as identical.

D.Choice: Men and women would have privileges they do not need.

Key.Rationale: In the passage, Tocqueville never claims that treating men and women the same would result in superfluous privileges for either.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 15-18 (“There ... alike”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Tocqueville implies would result from treating men and women as identical; instead, they discuss European approaches to such treatment, with no reference to the actual effects of it on men and women.

B.Choice: Lines 18-20 (“They ... rights”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Tocqueville implies would result from treating men and women as identical; instead, they discuss European approaches to such treatment, with no reference to the actual effects of it on men and women.

C.Choice: Lines 22-24 (“It may ... degraded”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks what Tocqueville implies would result from treating men and women as identical in nature. The answer, that he believes such treatment would harm both men and women, is supported in the second paragraph of Passage 1: “It may readily be conceived, that by thus attempting to make one sex equal to the other, both are degraded.”

D.Choice: Lines 27-29 (“It is ... sexes”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Tocqueville implies would result from treating men and women as identical; instead, they discuss what Tocqueville considers Americans' proper conception of equality as it relates to gender roles.

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 53, “dominion” most nearly means

A.Choice: omnipotence.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a paragraph discussing differences in the amount of power possessed by members of a society, “dominion” means supremacy, or greater power, not omnipotence, or the state of being all-powerful.

B.Choice: supremacy.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph of Passage 2, when discussing changing social relations, Mill writes that in her time there had come to exist “a just equality, instead of the dominion of the strongest.” In this context of a society where some had once wielded much greater power than others, the word “dominion” most nearly means supremacy, or greater power.

C.Choice: ownership.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a paragraph discussing differences in the amount of power possessed by members of a society, “dominion” means supremacy, or greater power, not ownership.

D.Choice: territory.

Key.Rationale: In the context of a paragraph discussing differences in the amount of power possessed by members of a society, “dominion” means supremacy, or greater power, not territory.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: In Passage 2, Mill most strongly suggests that gender roles are resistant to change because they

A.Choice: have long served as the basis for the formal organization of society.

Key.Rationale: Although Mill suggests in Passage 2 that gender roles are deeply entrenched, she does not imply that they serve as the foundation of society.

B.Choice: are matters of deeply entrenched tradition.

Key.Rationale: In the first paragraph of Passage 2, Mill suggests that social roles are resistant to change in part because of their being entrenched in the cultural tradition: “for, in proportion to the strength of a feeling is the tenacity with which it clings to the forms and circumstances with which it has even accidentally become associated.” In the context of a discussion of equality between men and women, Mill's statement serves to imply that gender roles change so slowly precisely because they are so deeply ingrained in society and culture.

C.Choice: can be influenced by legislative reforms only indirectly.

Key.Rationale: Passage 2 does not address the issue of legislative reforms, only societal ones.

D.Choice: benefit the groups and institutions currently in power.

Key.Rationale: Although Mill addresses the difficulty of reforming traditional gender roles, she does not attribute it to the benefits that certain groups or institutions derive from those roles.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 43-44 (“As society ... basis”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Mill implies is the reason it is hard to change gender roles, instead describing the condition of general inequality in prior eras.

B.Choice: Lines 46-49 (“two ... other”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Mill implies is the reason it is hard to change gender roles, instead describing the condition of general inequality in prior eras.

C.Choice: Lines 58-61 (“in proportion ... associated”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks about what Mill implies is the reason it is hard to change gender roles. The answer, that they are deeply entrenched in tradition, is supported in the first paragraph of Passage 2: “In proportion to the strength of a feeling is the tenacity with which it clings to the forms and circumstances with which it has even accidentally become associated.”

D.Choice: Lines 67-69 (“employments ... them”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about what Mill implies is the reason it is hard to change gender roles, instead optimistically considering a future society that she imagines will be less unequal.

SubTopics: Inferences, for which students must draw a reasonable inference based on explicit and/or implicit information and ideas in a text.
Content: Both authors would most likely agree that the changes in gender roles that they describe would be

A.Choice: part of a broad social shift toward greater equality.

Key.Rationale: Although the authors generally disagree about the roles men and women should occupy, both Tocqueville and Mill share the idea that gender equality is one small part of a societal shift toward equality in general. This can be seen in the first paragraph of Passage 1, where Tocqueville explains that raising woman to be “more and more the equal of man” is part of the overall “social changes which bring nearer to the same level the father and son, the master and servant,” and in the first paragraph of Passage 2, where Mill writes that “mankind have outgrown” the state of inequality and “now tend to substitute, as the general principle of human relations, a just equality,” with gender roles being the last of these relations to undergo such a shift.

B.Choice: unlikely to provide benefits that outweigh their costs.

Key.Rationale: Although in Passage 1 Tocqueville argues that there are costs to treating men and women the same, in Passage 2 Mill characterizes gender equality as a source of benefits only.

C.Choice: inevitable given the economic advantages of gender equality.

Key.Rationale: Neither author considers changing gender roles in terms of economic ramifications, focusing instead on questions of fairness and justice and the fulfillment of people's potential.

D.Choice: at odds with the principles of American democracy.

Key.Rationale: Mill does not discuss the issue in terms of American democracy, though Tocqueville does.

SubTopics: Cross-Text Connections, for which students must draw a reasonable connection between two topically related texts.
Content: Tocqueville in Passage 1 would most likely characterize the position taken by Mill in lines 65-69 in Passage 2 (“Let ... them”) as

A.Choice: less radical about gender roles than it might initially seem.

Key.Rationale: Tocqueville in Passage 1 never characterizes advocacy on behalf of gender equality (such as Mill engages in, in Passage 2) as less radical than it initially seems.

B.Choice: persuasive in the abstract but difficult to implement in practice.

Key.Rationale: Mill's stated belief that all jobs should be open to both men and women would clearly be refuted by Tocqueville as harmful to men and women alike.

C.Choice: ill-advised but consistent with a view held by some other advocates of gender equality.

Key.Rationale: In the second paragraph of Passage 2, Mill writes that she believes job opportunities in her society should be open to all: “Let every occupation be open to all, without favor or discouragement to any, and employments will fall into the hands of those men or women who are found by experience to be most capable of worthily exercising them.” In the second paragraph of Passage 1, Tocqueville argues that equality between men and women would leave both degraded; nonetheless, he recognizes that the belief in such equality is widespread: “There are people in Europe who ... would give to both the same functions, impose on both the same duties, and grant to both the same rights; they would mix them in all things — their occupations.” It can be inferred, then, that although Tocqueville would consider Mill's position ill-advised, he does recognize this position as one that is held by a number of reformers.

D.Choice: compatible with economic progress in the United States but not in Europe.

Key.Rationale: What Tocqueville praises the United States for is not gender equality as a component of economic progress, but rather the United States' division of activity into masculine and feminine spheres, which he likens to the division of labor in industrial production.

SubTopics: Cross-Text Connections, for which students must draw a reasonable connection between two topically related texts.
Content: Which choice best describes the ways that the two authors conceive of the individual's proper position in society?

A.Choice: Tocqueville believes that an individual's position should be defined in important ways by that individual's sex, while Mill believes that an individual's abilities should be the determining factor.

Key.Rationale: In Passage 1, Tocqueville argues that equality is generally beneficial for society, but he moderates that claim in the third paragraph by further stating that even if men and women should be considered equal, they should not work in the same jobs: “As nature has appointed such wide differences between the physical and moral constitution of man and woman, her manifest design was to give a distinct employment to their various faculties.” In contrast, Mill argues in the second paragraph of Passage 2 that men and women should be awarded work based on individual ability: “Let every occupation be open to all, without favor or discouragement to any, and employments will fall into the hands of those men or women who are found by experience to be most capable of worthily exercising them.” It can therefore be said that Tocqueville believes one's gender should play a determining factor in one's position in society, whereas Mill believes it should not.

B.Choice: Tocqueville believes that an individual's economic class should determine that individual's position, while Mill believes that class is not a legitimate consideration.

Key.Rationale: Both Tocqueville in Passage 1 and Mill in Passage 2 would likely argue against limiting an individual to the social class he or she was born to.

C.Choice: Tocqueville believes that an individual's temperament should determine that individual's position, while Mill believes that temperament should not be a factor in an individual's position.

Key.Rationale: It is Mill, not Tocqueville, who argues that individual temperament is the proper determining factor for social position.

D.Choice: Tocqueville believes that an individual's position should be determined by what is most beneficial to society, while Mill believes it should be determined by what an individual finds most rewarding.

Key.Rationale: Although it accurately represents Tocqueville's implicit stance that an individual's social position should contribute to society as a whole, it misrepresents Mill's argument, which conceives of social position in relation to individual aptitude, not individual satisfaction.

SubTopics: Cross-Text Connections, for which students must draw a reasonable connection between two topically related texts.
Content: Based on Passage 2, Mill would most likely say that the application of the “great principle of political economy” (lines 38-39, Passage 1) to gender roles has which effect?

A.Choice: It prevents many men and women from developing to their full potential.

Key.Rationale: In the third paragraph of Passage 1, Tocqueville credits the Americans of his time for applying “to the sexes the great principle of political economy ... by carefully dividing the duties of man from those of woman.” In contrast, in the second paragraph of Passage 2, Mill argues that rigid social roles function to “declare that whatever be the genius, talent, energy, or force of mind, of an individual of a certain sex or class, those faculties shall not be exerted.” It can be inferred, then, that Mill would argue that the principle praised by Tocqueville tends to limit both men and women from developing their full potential.

B.Choice: It makes it difficult for men and women to sympathize with each other.

Key.Rationale: In Passage 2, Mill focuses her argument on gender roles and equality between sexes but never addresses the idea of sympathy between them.

C.Choice: It unintentionally furthers the cause of gender equality.

Key.Rationale: Mill considers the division of professions by gender as a perpetuation of a long tradition of gender inequality.

D.Choice: It guarantees that women take occupations that men are better suited to perform.

Key.Rationale: Although Mill suggests that gender equality would involve rethinking the professional options available to men and women, she dismisses the notion that one gender is better suited to certain professions or would displace the other gender in certain professions.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: Over the course of the passage, the main focus shifts from

A.Choice: a technical account of the Higgs field to a description of it aimed at a broad audience.

Key.Rationale: The passage makes no shift from a more to a less technical mode of description, and indeed the entire passage is aimed at readers with no specialized knowledge of physics.

B.Choice: a review of Higgs's work to a contextualization of that work with in Higgs's era.

Key.Rationale: The passage never provides any contextualization of Higgs's work within other lines of inquiry in physics contemporary to Higgs.

C.Choice: an explanation of the Higgs field to a discussion of the response to Higgs's theory.

Key.Rationale: The passage's first two paragraphs describe how “Peter Higgs and a handful of other physicists were trying to understand the origin of a basic physical feature: mass,” and the third paragraph discusses the idea put forth (“now called the Higgs field”) to explain the environment where mathematical equations are most helpful in understanding mass. The passage shifts its focus, however: the fourth and fifth paragraphs describe how the idea of the Higgs field was not initially well-received in the scientific community, and the last paragraph illustrates that in modern times, the idea ultimately became an accepted fact to most scientists. Over the course of the passage, then, it can be seen that the main focus of the passage changes from an explanation of what the Higgs field is to an explanation of how the theory of it was received.

D.Choice: an analysis of the Higgs field to a suggestion of future discoveries that might build upon it.

Key.Rationale: The passage offers no speculation regarding future discoveries that may result from the confirmation of the Higgs field's existence.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: The main purpose of the analogy of the ping-pong ball (line 40) is to

A.Choice: popularize a little-known fact.

Key.Rationale: The analogy of the ping-pong ball is used in the passage to help laypeople understand the difficult concept of the Higgs field, rather than to make a little-known fact more widely known.

B.Choice: contrast competing scientific theories.

Key.Rationale: The analogy of the ping-pong ball is used in the passage to help laypeople understand the difficult concept of the Higgs field, rather than to draw a contrast between oppositional scientific theories.

C.Choice: criticize a widely accepted explanation.

Key.Rationale: The analogy of the ping-pong ball is used in the passage to help laypeople understand the difficult concept of the Higgs field, rather than to refute any established explanation.

D.Choice: clarify an abstract concept.

Key.Rationale: The third paragraph of the passage provides the following analogy: “For a mental toehold, think of a ping-pong ball submerged in water.” Since this analogy occurs in a discussion of how mass operates within the Higgs field, it functions to explain an abstract concept in terms more readily grasped by readers with no background in physics.

SubTopics: Central Ideas and Details, for which students must determine the central idea of a text and/or interpret the key details supporting that idea.
Content: The author most strongly suggests that the reason the scientific community initially rejected Higgs's idea was that the idea

A.Choice: addressed a problem unnoticed by other physicists.

Key.Rationale: The passage makes clear that Higgs's idea addressed a theoretical problem already recognized by scientists, rather than a problem yet to be noticed by them.

B.Choice: only worked if the equations were flawless.

Key.Rationale: The fourth paragraph implies that Higgs's paper was rigorous (free from “technical error”), rather than problematic at the level of its equations.

C.Choice: rendered accepted theories in physics obsolete.

Key.Rationale: The passage never indicates that the acceptance of the Higgs field had the effect of rendering other, earlier theories in physics obsolete.

D.Choice: appeared to have little empirical basis.

Key.Rationale: The fourth paragraph of the passage explains why Higgs's idea of the Higgs field was initially rebuffed by the scientific community: “The paper was rejected. Not because it contained a technical error, but because the premise of an invisible something permeating space, interacting with particles to provide their mass, well, it all just seemed like heaps of overwrought speculation.” In other words, the scientific community was skeptical of Higgs's idea because it appeared to be mere theoretical speculation, with no empirical evidence to support it.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 30-32 (“Instead ... environment”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the scientific community initially rejected the idea of the Higgs field, instead discussing how Higgs dealt with established equations in physics when he theorized the field.

B.Choice: Lines 46-48 (“In 1964 ... mathematically”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the scientific community initially rejected the idea of the Higgs field, instead describing the circumstances in which Higgs revealed his theory to the scientific community.

C.Choice: Lines 48-53 (“Not ... speculation”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks why the scientific community initially rejected the idea of the Higgs field. The answer, that Higgs offered only theoretical speculation for the existence of the field, not actual evidence, is supported in the fourth paragraph: “The paper was rejected. Not because it contained a technical error, but because the premise of an invisible something permeating space, interacting with particles to provide their mass, well, it all just seemed like heaps of overwrought speculation.”

D.Choice: Lines 67-70 (“The physics ... space”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the scientific community initially rejected the idea of the Higgs field, instead illustrating the fact that the Higgs field eventually came to be an accepted fact to most scientists.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: The author notes that one reason Higgs's theory gained acceptance was that it

A.Choice: let scientists accept two conditions that had previously seemed irreconcilable.

Key.Rationale: The fifth paragraph of the passage explains how the idea of the Higgs field eventually came to be accepted in the scientific community: “But Higgs persevered (and his revised paper appeared later that year in another journal), and physicists who took the time to study the proposal gradually realized that his idea was a stroke of genius, one that allowed them to have their cake and eat it too. In Higgs's scheme, the fundamental equations can retain their pristine form because the dirty work of providing the particles' masses is relegated to the environment.” In saying that the Higgs field came to be accepted because it allowed scientists to “have their cake and eat it too,” the author suggests that Higgs's theory was ultimately accepted as fact in part because it allowed physicists to reconcile what had seemed to be contradictory conditions: the harmony of the mathematical equations and the particles' apparent mass.

B.Choice: introduced an innovative approach that could be applied to additional problems.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not suggest that the Higgs field was necessarily a concept that could be applied to other problems in physics than those immediately under Higgs's consideration.

C.Choice: answered a question that earlier scientists had not even raised.

Key.Rationale: The passage does not suggest that Higgs's theory was accepted because it provided an answer to a question that earlier scientists had failed to anticipate.

D.Choice: explained why two distinct phenomena were being misinterpreted as one phenomenon.

Key.Rationale: The passage never addresses any two phenomena being misinterpreted as a single phenomenon.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?

A.Choice: Lines 36-39 (“Push ... mass”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the Higgs field eventually gained acceptance in the scientific community, instead explaining certain aspects of the Higgs field.

B.Choice: Lines 43-45 (“Its interaction ... field”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the Higgs field eventually gained acceptance in the scientific community, instead explaining certain aspects of the Higgs field.

C.Choice: Lines 55-63 (“But ... environment”)

Key.Rationale: The previous question asks for one reason Higgs's theory eventually gained acceptance in the scientific community. The answer, that it reconciled two seemingly irreconcilable conditions, is supported in the passage's fifth paragraph: “But Higgs persevered (and his revised paper appeared later that year in another journal), and physicists who took the time to study the proposal gradually realized that his idea was a stroke of genius, one that allowed them to have their cake and eat it too. In Higgs's scheme, the fundamental equations can retain their pristine form because the dirty work of providing the particles' masses is relegated to the environment.” These lines make clear that Higgs's theory allowed for the particles' mass, while at the same time accepting the fundamental equations as valid.

D.Choice: Lines 78-83 (“On occasion ... them”)

Key.Rationale: The lines cited do not support the answer to the previous question about why the Higgs field eventually gained acceptance in the scientific community, instead discussing how certain scientific theories become accepted as fact even before they are proven.

SubTopics: Command of Evidence (Textual), for which students must use textual evidence (e.g., a fact, detail, or example) to appropriately support, challenge, or otherwise respond to a specified claim or point.
Content: Which statement best describes the technique the author uses to advance the main point of the last paragraph?

A.Choice: He recounts a personal experience to illustrate a characteristic of the discipline of physics.

Key.Rationale: The main point of the last paragraph can be seen in its final sentence, which states that “mathematical equations can sometimes tell such a convincing tale, they can seemingly radiate reality so strongly, that they become entrenched in the vernacular of working physicists, even before there's data to confirm them.” This point is borne out by the preceding lines of the paragraph, which recount the author's own experience of studying the still unproven Higgs field as it if were already a settled fact.

B.Choice: He describes his own education to show how physics has changed during his career.

Key.Rationale: The anecdote the author shares about his own education does not demonstrate that physics, as a discipline, has come to operate differently over the course of his career.

C.Choice: He provides autobiographical details to demonstrate how Higgs's theory was confirmed.

Key.Rationale: The details of the author's experience do not point to the process by which the existence of the Higgs field was confirmed, and indeed the passage does not describe that process at all.

D.Choice: He contrasts the status of Higgs's theory at two time periods to reveal how the details of the theory evolved.

Key.Rationale: The passage broadly discusses the status of Higgs's theory at two different times (its initial rejection and later acceptance by physicists) and never considers how the details of the theory may have evolved.

SubTopics: Words in Context, for which students must determine the meaning of a high-utility academic word or phrase in context or use such vocabulary in a precise, contextually appropriate way.
Content: As used in line 77, “established” most nearly means

A.Choice: validated.

Key.Rationale: In the last paragraph, the author states that “the professor presented the Higgs field with such certainty that for a long while I had no idea it had yet to be established experimentally.” In this context, for a scientific theory to be established most nearly means that it is validated, or proven.

B.Choice: founded.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the last paragraph describing a scientific theory as being “established experimentally,” the word “established” means validated, or proven, not founded.

C.Choice: introduced.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the last paragraph describing a scientific theory as being “established experimentally,” the word “established” means validated, or proven, not introduced.

D.Choice: enacted.

Key.Rationale: In the context of the last paragraph describing a scientific theory as being “established experimentally,” the word “established” means validated, or proven, not enacted.

SubTopics: Text Structure and Purpose, for which students must analyze the structure of a text or determine the main rhetorical purpose of a text.
Content: What purpose does the graph serve in relation to the passage as a whole?

A.Choice: It indicates that the scientific community's quick acceptance of the Higgs boson was typical.

Key.Rationale: The graph illustrates that the Higgs boson required significantly more time to be confirmed than did any of the other theorized particles.

B.Choice: It places the discussion of the reception of the Higgs boson into a broader scientific context.

Key.Rationale: The graph shows the periods of time that transpired between the moment when certain scientific concepts were introduced and the moment when those concepts were scientifically proven.
